definitions.definition: to describe somebody/something as being very good or special, especially in newspapers, etc.
definitions.sensetop: be hailed (as) somethinghail somebody/something as something

examples.text: The conference was hailed as a great success.
The expedition was widely hailed as a success.
Teenager Matt Brown is being hailed a hero for saving a young child from drowning.
Union leaders hailed the socialists’ victory as a huge step forward.

definitions.definition: to signal to a taxi or a bus, in order to get the driver to stop
to call to somebody in order to say hello to them or attract their attention

examples.text: A voice hailed us from the other side of the street.
We soon came **within hailing distance of** *(= fairly close to)* the others.

definitions.definition: when it hails, small balls of ice fall like rain from the sky

wordOrigin: verb sense 4 Old English hagol, hægl (noun), hagalian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch hagel and German Hagel. verb senses 1 to 3 Middle English: from the obsolete adjective hail ‘healthy’ (occurring in greetings and toasts, such as wæs hæil: see wassail), from Old Norse heill, related to hale and whole.
